title: Can former presidents vote in presidential elections? - Quora

response.answer_text: Feel like the better question is “Why would it matter”. Former President votes count for the same as John Q. Public’s vote: one. They lose their veto power when they leave office, so their only ability to influence elections is if they publicly speak out about the candidates, which as a matter of professional respect, rarely happens. Something significant has to change for former Presidents to come out and say things like: “I think ultimately the restraints on a president from the Congress and from the Supreme Court will be adequate to protect our nation, if he serves a full term.” - Former Pres. response.answer_text: Generally yes, unless they are a convicted felon. My understanding is that doesn’t apply to any of the living former POTUS. However, perhaps in Chicago, JFK and/or LBJ and/or FDR could vote during 2020, 2024, etc.? That’s part of how hiz-honor Richard Daley delivered Illinois to JFK in 1960.

Yes! In fact, I just saw an article talking about George H W Bush voting in the 2018 election. (The article was about his service dog, Sully. Here is a picture of Bush and Sully at their polling place. Sully, being under the age of 18 and also a dog, is just there to assist.)
Former presidents can vote. Just because you become the POTUS, does not mean you are suddenly stripped of your Constitutional rights after leaving office.
Of course they can. As a former President they are private citizens just like any other private citizen and, barring a felony conviction, have the right to vote.
